BastionZero is reimagining the tools used to control remote access to servers, containers and clusters in the cloud. BastionZero deploys in minutes, autodiscovers your targets, automatically integrates with your SSO provider, and logs and monitors remote access by your users or their scripts.  Our unique key-splitting technology provides all the benefits of zero trust, without storing the credentials to your targets in a centralized authority that can get hacked.

Education: Ph.D. student in Gyorgy Buzsaki's lab at Rutgers and then NYU.  Recording of spikes and local field potentials from hippocampus in freely moving rats using tetrodes and silicon probes.  Data analysis, including creation of a MATLAB package for wavelet analysis, novel methods for accurate detection of ripple events, current source density analysis, and more.  Juxtacelluar recording and labeling of hippocampal neurons, along with immunohistochemistry and fluorescence microscopy to identify cell type.  Managed and analyzed large datasets collected from multiple experimentalists. Built and maintained Linux servers for lab use.  First author or co-author on multiple papers.
Experience: Postdoctoral researcher first in the lab of the late Howard Eichenbaum (2013-2017) and then jointly in the labs of Michael Hasselmo and Marc Howard (2017-present).  Coordinated the introduction to the Eichenbaum lab of single-photon calcium imaging in freely-moving mice using Inscopix miniaturized fluorescence microscopes.  Created a novel algorithm and software package, TENASPIS, for efficiently extracting neuronal activity from movies recorded with these microscopes, using MATLAB and its image processing toolbox; this package has been widely used by lab colleagues.  Managed and trained an undergraduate student who then became a lab assistant under my supervision, and went on to become a neuroscience Ph.D. student. Performed experiments in freely moving mice to compare the way hippocampal neurons respond to tasks that are either primary spatial or temporal in nature.  Co-author on multiple publications.

Neural network modeling in William B (Chip) Levy's lab.  Programming and running simulations using custom software written in C++ and parallelized using MPI.  First author or co-author on multiple papers.

Contractor position, working with the ESX hypervisor team. Developed cache occupancy modeling and cache-aware scheduling strategies for performance isolation between guests.

Developed embedded system software/hardware for laser measurement gauges used in the wire industry. Experience with Intel 80196 microcontrollers, Texas Instruments 9900 assembler, embedded C programming, and firmware.

PhD research on architectural geometry. Jointly hosted by the Computer Graphics Group in the MIT Department of Computer Science, and the Building Technology Group in the MIT Department of Architecture.

I worked on machine learning and optimization algorithms. My advisor was Kwabena Boahen. Most of my research concerned designing learning algorithms that provably do not require hyperparameter tuning. As part of my work, I invented the first online learning algorithm that achieves the optimal convergence rate without hyperparameters.

I designed and implemented a communication-efficient distributed stochastic optimization algorithm for large-scale machine learning.  I created a novel reduction allowing for parallelization of any serial stochastic gradient descent algorithm while achieving the optimal communication complexity.  I then implemented this algorithm in the Spark framework, and achieved significant improvements in both final loss and runtime over prior methods on large-scale ad-click prediction datasets
